dialogue: Hi! I'm Alex, a virtual assistant, here to talk about participating in cancer clinical research. My goal is to give you information to help you understand what clinical research can mean during the cancer journey. Ready to get started?

Alright, first we will discuss health insurance. Having health insurance (including Medicare or Medicaid) makes participating in a cancer clinical research study easier. Insurance usually covers most medical treatment costs. Additionally, the study sponsor (like the university, government, or drug company in charge of the study) can help cover costs. If you don't have insurance, there are clinical research studies out there whose study sponsor covers all costs. Also, the National Cancer Institute Community Oncology Research Program has studies for people with lower income, and could be a good option.

Next, let’s talk about treatment during clinical trials. A lot of clinical research relies on randomly deciding the treatment, meaning you wouldn’t get to choose if you get the standard or new treatment. If you prefer the standard treatment, there are research studies that don’t offer treatment, so you might be able to continue standard care. If you want the new treatment, there are research studies that only offer the latest treatment, although these studies have higher risks involved.

Now, it’s important to understand that many clinical research studies use a computer to randomly decide your treatment, so your doctor doesn’t get to choose – this is called randomization. Your doctor can talk you through the possible treatments you might get so you feel more comfortable. Being okay with randomization increases the likelihood of someone being in clinical research. If you aren’t comfortable with a computer deciding your treatment, there are research studies that don’t involve randomization or taking any treatment.

Moving on, choosing to be in a study is an important decision and you should talk about it with your doctor and family members or friends. If anyone in your family has any questions about clinical trials your doctor (or someone on the study team) can help. When everyone in your family is comfortable with your decision, it can make being in a study a little easier. If your family is already on board with you being in clinical research, that helps make participation smoother.

The next topic is about trust – whether or not you decide to join a trial may be affected by how you feel about cancer doctors or researchers. If you generally trust doctors and researchers, this makes participating in clinical research easier. If you have trouble trusting doctors and hospitals that do research, participating in clinical research may be hard. However, there are many ways that patients are protected when they participate in research studies. Giving cancer patients the best, most ethical care is important to doctors and researchers.

Finally, there are many reasons to participate in cancer clinical research. Some people participate in cancer research to improve cancer care for others. People also join because they want a chance to receive the newest treatment or get extra care from the clinical trial staff. Ultimately, the choice should be based on your personal values as well as the facts about clinical research.

Many costs related to clinical trial participation can be covered. Routine patient care costs, like doctor visits, hospital stays, standard treatments, and lab tests, may be paid by health insurance. Research costs, which are specific to the trial, such as experimental drugs or extra tests, might be paid for by the trial sponsor. Some trials help with travel costs, lodging, meals, and even childcare if participants need to travel for the study. It's important for participants to ask the study team about what costs are covered before joining
Now, do you think your family would be okay with you participating in cancer clinical research?

Great! Choosing to be in a study is an important decision and you should talk about it with your doctor and family members or friends. If anyone in your family has any questions about clinical trials your doctor (or someone on the study team) can help. People like you, who have family support, tend to be more likely to join clinical research studies!

I see. Choosing to be in a study is an important decision and you should talk about it with your doctor and family members or friends. Your doctor and the members of the study team can help answer any questions your family members have. When everyone in your family is comfortable with your decision, it can make being in a study a little easier.
Moving on, do you generally trust doctors and researchers who do cancer research?

options.optionText: Yes, I trust doctors and researchers.
No, I do not trust doctors and researchers.

dialogue: That's great! Whether or not you decide to join a trial may be affected by how you feel about cancer doctors or researchers. People like you who generally trust doctors and researchers who conduct cancer research are more likely to participate in clinical research! Giving cancer patients the best, most ethical care is important to doctors and researchers.

That's okay -- whether or not you decide to join a trial may be affected by how you feel about cancer doctors or researchers. If you have trouble trusting doctors and hospitals that do research, participating in clinical research may be hard. And that’s okay. However, there are many ways that patients are protected when they participate in research studies. Giving cancer patients the best, most ethical care is important to doctors and researchers.
Finally, is it important to you to help others who might be affected with your type of cancer in the future?

options.optionText: Yes, I want to help others by participating in research.
No, helping others is not a priority for me.

dialogue: Like you, many people participate in cancer research to improve cancer care for others! People also join because they want a chance to receive the newest treatment or get extra care from the clinical trial staff. People like you, who join to help others, are more likely to join cancer research!

Of course, your choice should be based on your personal values as well as the facts about clinical research. Clinical research can offer many benefits for you – for example, it’s a chance to receive the newest treatment or to get extra care from clinical trial staff.

Helping others is one reason why many people join clinical trials, but others join for personal benefits such as a chance to receive the newest treatment or to get extra care from clinical trial staff. Your choice should be based on your personal values as well as the facts about clinical research.
Okay, thanks for chatting with me today! That's all the topics I wanted to talk about. If you have anymore questions, feel free to ask, or you can click 'I'm Done'.
